summary: endoplasmic reticulum (ER2) is responsible for folding, maturation, and trafficking of most secretory and membrane proteins. ER stress occurs when the nascent protein loading exceeds the ER folding capacity under circumstances such as virus infection, gene mutation, calcium flux perturbation, or glucose deprivation. ER stress activates the unfolded protein response (UPR) to suppress general protein synthesis and increase the ER folding capacity. IRE1 is a type I transmembrane protein with both endoribonuclease and kinase activity. the other isoform, IRE1, is found only in the epithelial cells of gastrointestinal track (7) and airway (8). IRE1 also forms a complex with the adaptor protein TNFR-associated factor 2 (TRAF2) to activate apoptosis signal-regulating kinase 1 (ASK1) and JNK the mTORC1 complex contains the regulatory-associated protein of mammalian target of rapamycin (Raptor) and proline-rich Akt substrate 40 kDa. the mTORC2 complex also contains the regulatory-associated protein of mammalian target of rapamycin (Raptor) and proline-rich Akt substrate 40 kDa (PRAS40) mTORC1 was activated under ER stress conditions by ER calcium depletion by ER calcium ATPase blockage. TSC1- or TSC2-deficient cells showed increased phosphorylation of S6, IRE1 and JNK.
